title: Getting Started with Claude Code
description: A comprehensive beginner's guide to AI-assisted development with Claude Code CLI
body:
# Getting Started with Claude Code

Claude Code is a powerful CLI tool that brings AI-assisted development directly to your terminal. Unlike traditional chatbots, Claude Code understands your entire codebase and can make changes across multiple files.

## Installation

```bash
npm install -g @anthropic-ai/claude-code
```

## First Steps

1. Navigate to your project directory
2. Run `claude` to start an interactive session
3. Ask Claude to explore your codebase

## Key Features

- **Codebase awareness**: Claude reads and understands your entire project
- **Multi-file editing**: Make coordinated changes across files
- **Git integration**: Commit, review, and manage PRs
- **Extensible**: Add custom commands and MCP servers

## Your First Task

Try asking Claude: "What does this project do and what's its structure?"

Claude will explore your codebase and give you a comprehensive overview. From there, you can start making changes, fixing bugs, or adding features.

## Next Steps

- Learn about Plan Mode for complex tasks
- Explore custom commands in `.claude/commands/`
- Set up MCP servers for external integrations

title: Mastering Prompting Techniques for Claude Code
description: Learn how to write effective prompts that get better results from AI coding assistants
body:
# Mastering Prompting Techniques

The quality of your prompts directly impacts the quality of Claude's responses. Here's how to get the most out of your AI coding assistant.

## The Anatomy of a Good Prompt

1. **Be specific**: Instead of "fix the bug", say "fix the null pointer exception in UserService.getUserById"
2. **Provide context**: Reference specific files with `@filename`
3. **State your constraints**: "Use TypeScript, follow existing patterns"
4. **Define success**: "The test should pass after the fix"

## Examples

### Bad Prompt
```
Make the code better
```

### Good Prompt
```
Refactor the authentication flow in @src/auth/auth.service.ts to:
1. Use async/await consistently
2. Add proper error handling
3. Follow the existing error pattern in @src/common/errors.ts
```

## Advanced Techniques

### Chain of Thought
Ask Claude to think step by step for complex problems:
```
Analyze the performance issue in the article listing endpoint. 
First, identify the bottleneck, then propose solutions.
```

### Negative Prompting
Tell Claude what NOT to do:
```
Add validation to this form. Don't use any external libraries.
```

## Practice Makes Perfect

Start simple and iterate. Watch how Claude interprets your prompts and adjust accordingly.

title: Understanding MCP Servers in Claude Code
description: Deep dive into Model Context Protocol servers and how they extend Claude's capabilities
body:
# Understanding MCP Servers

MCP (Model Context Protocol) servers are the secret weapon that makes Claude Code incredibly powerful. They allow Claude to interact with external systems like databases, APIs, and documentation.

## What are MCP Servers?

MCP servers are lightweight programs that expose tools and resources to Claude. When you configure an MCP server, Claude gains new abilities.

## Popular MCP Servers

### MongoDB MCP
```json
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "mongodb": {
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["@anthropic-ai/mcp-mongo", "mongodb://localhost:27017"]
    }
  }
}
```

With this, Claude can:
- Query your database
- Understand your data structure
- Write queries based on actual data

### Context7 (Documentation)
Look up framework documentation in real-time:
```
Look up NestJS guards documentation using Context7
```

### Puppeteer/Playwright
Browser automation and testing:
- Take screenshots
- Interact with web pages
- Debug UI issues

## Creating Custom MCP Servers

You can create your own MCP servers for:
- Internal APIs
- Custom databases
- Proprietary systems

## Best Practices

1. Use read-only connections for production databases
2. Limit scope to what's necessary
3. Document available tools for your team

title: AI-Assisted Code Review: A New Paradigm
description: How AI tools are transforming the code review process and improving code quality
body:
# AI-Assisted Code Review

Code review is essential but time-consuming. AI can help reviewers focus on what matters most.

## The Traditional Problem

- Reviews take hours
- Reviewers miss things when tired
- Style nitpicks distract from logic issues
- Context switching is expensive

## Enter AI-Assisted Review

With Claude Code's `/review` command, you can:

1. **Automate the obvious**: Catch style issues, unused imports, simple bugs
2. **Get context**: AI explains what changed and why it matters
3. **Focus human attention**: Reviewers focus on architecture and business logic

## Setting Up Review Workflows

```yaml
# .claude/commands/review.md
---
name: review
description: Review code changes
---

Review the staged changes. Focus on:
1. Security issues
2. Performance problems
3. Logic errors
4. Test coverage

Provide actionable feedback.
```

## Real-World Results

Teams using AI-assisted review report:
- 40% faster review cycles
- Fewer bugs reaching production
- More consistent feedback
- Better knowledge sharing

## The Human Element

AI doesn't replace human reviewers. It augments them. Use AI for the first pass, humans for the final say.

title: Automating Git Workflows with Claude Code
description: Streamline your Git operations with AI-powered commit messages and PR descriptions
body:
# Automating Git Workflows

Git is powerful but verbose. Claude Code can handle the tedious parts while you focus on coding.

## Smart Commits with /commit

The `/commit` command analyzes your changes and generates meaningful commit messages:

```bash
# Instead of thinking about what to write...
claude /commit

# Claude analyzes diff and generates:
# feat(auth): add password reset functionality
#
# - Add forgot password endpoint
# - Implement email service integration
# - Add password reset token validation
```

## Conventional Commits

Claude follows conventional commit format:
- `feat`: New features
- `fix`: Bug fixes
- `refactor`: Code improvements
- `docs`: Documentation
- `test`: Test changes

## Pull Request Generation

The `/pr` command creates comprehensive PR descriptions:

1. Summarizes all commits
2. Lists files changed
3. Highlights breaking changes
4. Suggests reviewers

## Branch Management

Ask Claude to:
- Create feature branches with good names
- Rebase and resolve conflicts
- Cherry-pick commits

## Tips

1. Stage related changes together
2. Let Claude see the full diff
3. Provide context for better messages

title: Understanding Context Windows in AI Coding
description: How context windows work and strategies for working with large codebases
body:
# Understanding Context Windows

Context windows are the amount of text an AI can "see" at once. Understanding this is key to effective AI-assisted coding.

## What is a Context Window?

Think of it as the AI's working memory. Claude's context window is large (200K tokens), but your codebase might be larger.

## Strategies for Large Codebases

### 1. Use @file References
```
Look at @src/auth/auth.service.ts and @src/auth/auth.controller.ts
```
This tells Claude exactly what to focus on.

### 2. Leverage CLAUDE.md
Your project's CLAUDE.md file gives Claude persistent context about:
- Project structure
- Coding conventions
- Common commands

### 3. Work in Focused Sessions
Instead of:
```
Refactor the entire codebase
```

Try:
```
Refactor the authentication module
```

### 4. Use Summarization
Ask Claude to summarize large files before working on them.

## Monitoring Context Usage

Claude Code shows context usage in the status bar. Watch for:
- Files being read
- Conversation history size
- Tool outputs

## Best Practices

1. Start fresh sessions for new tasks
2. Be specific about what files to read
3. Use Plan Mode for exploration
4. Trust Claude's codebase understanding

title: Claude Code vs Cursor vs Copilot: An Honest Comparison
description: A practical comparison of popular AI coding tools and when to use each
body:
# AI Coding Tools Compared

Let's cut through the marketing and look at what each tool actually does well.

## GitHub Copilot

**Best for**: Autocomplete, inline suggestions

**Strengths**:
- Fast inline completions
- Works in any IDE
- Good for boilerplate

**Limitations**:
- No codebase awareness
- Can't make multi-file changes
- No conversation memory

## Cursor

**Best for**: IDE-integrated AI experience

**Strengths**:
- Full IDE with AI built-in
- Good autocomplete
- Chat sidebar

**Limitations**:
- Must switch IDEs
- Less agentic than Claude Code
- Limited extensibility

## Claude Code

**Best for**: Complex, multi-file tasks

**Strengths**:
- Agentic execution
- Full codebase understanding
- MCP extensibility
- Custom commands
- Works alongside any IDE

**Limitations**:
- CLI learning curve
- Requires API access
- No inline autocomplete

## The Verdict

They're not mutually exclusive:

1. Use **Copilot** for quick completions
2. Use **Claude Code** for complex tasks, refactoring, debugging
3. Use **Cursor** if you want one integrated experience

Many developers use Claude Code + Copilot together successfully.

title: Building Custom Commands for Your Team
description: Create reusable AI workflows that enforce team standards and boost productivity
body:
# Building Custom Commands

Custom commands turn your team's best practices into repeatable workflows.

## Command Basics

Commands live in `.claude/commands/` as Markdown files:

```markdown
---
name: quality-check
description: Run quality checks on code
---

Run the following checks and fix any issues:

1. Run linter: `npm run lint`
2. Run type checker: `npm run typecheck`
3. Run tests: `npm run test`

Fix any issues found. Report what was fixed.
```

## Command Features

### Arguments
```markdown
---
name: feature
description: Plan and implement a feature
---

Implement the following feature:

$ARGUMENTS

Follow our coding standards in CLAUDE.md.
```

Usage: `/feature Add user avatar upload`

### Allowed Tools
```yaml
---
allowed-tools:
  - Read
  - Edit
  - Bash(npm run:*)
---
```

## Team Command Ideas

| Command | Purpose |
|---------|----------|
| `/commit` | Smart conventional commits |
| `/pr` | Generate PR descriptions |
| `/test` | Generate unit tests |
| `/doc` | Generate documentation |
| `/review` | AI code review |
| `/debug` | Systematic debugging |

## Sharing Commands

1. Add to version control
2. Share via claude plugins
3. Document in team wiki

Commands become your team's institutional knowledge.

title: AI-Powered Test Generation That Actually Works
description: Practical strategies for generating useful tests with AI assistance
body:
# AI-Powered Test Generation

AI can generate tests, but making them useful requires the right approach.

## The Problem with Naive Test Generation

"Generate tests for this file" often produces:
- Tests that pass but test nothing
- Mocked everything (no real testing)
- Brittle assertions

## A Better Approach

### 1. Test the Behavior, Not Implementation

```
Generate tests for UserService that verify:
1. Creating a user with valid data succeeds
2. Creating a user with duplicate email fails
3. Password is never returned in responses
```

### 2. Provide Examples

```
Generate tests following the pattern in @tests/auth.spec.ts
```

### 3. Focus on Edge Cases

```
Generate edge case tests for the article slug generation:
- Empty titles
- Special characters
- Very long titles
- Unicode characters
```

## TDD with AI

The `/fix-bug-tdd` command workflow:

1. Write a failing test for the bug
2. AI implements the fix
3. Test passes
4. Refactor if needed

## Test Quality Checklist

- [ ] Tests actual behavior
- [ ] Meaningful assertions
- [ ] Tests failure cases
- [ ] Readable test names
- [ ] Minimal mocking

## Real Results

Teams report 60-80% of AI-generated tests are useful after refinement. The key is iteration.

title: Debugging with AI: A Systematic Approach
description: How to leverage AI for faster, more effective debugging sessions
body:
# Debugging with AI

AI excels at debugging when you give it the right information.

## The Debugging Workflow

### Step 1: Gather Context
```
I'm getting this error:
[paste error]

It happens when:
[describe scenario]

Relevant files:
@src/articles/articles.service.ts
@src/articles/articles.controller.ts
```

### Step 2: Reproduce
Ask Claude to help create a minimal reproduction:
```
Help me write a test that reproduces this error
```

### Step 3: Analyze
```
Analyze the code path from the controller to where the error occurs.
Explain what's happening step by step.
```

### Step 4: Fix
```
Fix the issue. Explain the root cause.
```

## MCP Integration for Debugging

### With MongoDB MCP
```
The user with id X is getting an error.
Query the database for this user and their articles.
What's wrong with the data?
```

### With Datadog MCP
```
Look at the error logs for the past hour.
Find patterns in the failures.
```

## Common Debugging Prompts

- "Why might this return undefined?"
- "What's the race condition here?"
- "Trace the data flow from input to error"
- "What edge cases does this not handle?"

## Tips

1. Include full error messages
2. Describe what you expected
3. Share relevant logs
4. Mention recent changes

title: Plan Mode: Thinking Before Coding
description: How to use Plan Mode for complex tasks that require exploration first
body:
# Plan Mode: Think First

Plan Mode is Claude Code's secret weapon for complex tasks. It lets you explore without making changes.

## When to Use Plan Mode

- Exploring unfamiliar codebases
- Planning large refactors
- Investigating bugs
- Understanding architecture

## How It Works

1. Press `Ctrl+P` or type `/plan`
2. Claude switches to read-only mode
3. Explore, ask questions, analyze
4. When ready, exit and implement

## Plan Mode Workflow

### 1. Explore
```
Show me how authentication works in this project.
Trace from login to JWT validation.
```

### 2. Understand
```
What patterns does this codebase use for error handling?
Show me examples.
```

### 3. Plan
```
I need to add role-based access control.
What files would need to change?
What's the best approach given the existing patterns?
```

### 4. Execute
Exit Plan Mode and implement with confidence.

## Real Example

Task: "Add article bookmarking"

Plan Mode exploration:
1. How are favorites implemented?
2. What's the data model pattern?
3. What endpoints exist?
4. What tests should I add?

Then implement with a clear picture.

## Tips

- Use Thinking toggle for deeper analysis
- Reference files with @filename
- Ask "what if" questions
- Let Claude propose the plan

title: The CLAUDE.md File: Your Project's AI Memory
description: How to create an effective CLAUDE.md file that helps AI understand your project
body:
# The CLAUDE.md File

CLAUDE.md is your project's instruction manual for AI. Get it right and Claude becomes incredibly effective.

## What Goes in CLAUDE.md

### 1. Project Overview
```markdown
# CLAUDE.md

This is a NestJS API for a blogging platform.
Uses MongoDB with Mongoose ODM.
```

### 2. Common Commands
```markdown
## Commands

npm run start:dev    # Development server
npm run test         # Unit tests
npm run lint         # Linting
```

### 3. Architecture Notes
```markdown
## Architecture

- Modules in src/{feature}/
- Schemas in src/schemas/
- DTOs for validation
- Guards for auth
```

### 4. Coding Conventions
```markdown
## Conventions

- Use async/await
- Throw HttpException for errors
- Follow existing patterns
```

## Creating CLAUDE.md

Run `/init` and Claude will:
1. Analyze your codebase
2. Generate initial CLAUDE.md
3. You can refine it

## Memory Hierarchy

1. **CLAUDE.md** - Project-level
2. **~/.claude/CLAUDE.md** - User-level
3. **Session memory** - Conversation context

## Tips

- Keep it concise
- Focus on non-obvious things
- Update as project evolves
- Include common pitfalls

## Anti-Patterns

- Don't repeat obvious things
- Don't include secrets
- Don't list every file

title: Refactoring Legacy Code with AI Assistance
description: Strategies for safely modernizing legacy codebases using AI tools
body:
# Refactoring Legacy Code with AI

Legacy code is scary. AI makes it less so.

## The Challenge

- No tests
- No documentation
- Original developers gone
- Fear of breaking things

## AI-Assisted Approach

### Step 1: Understand

Use Plan Mode:
```
Explain what this module does.
Identify the main responsibilities.
List the dependencies.
```

### Step 2: Document

Before changing, document:
```
Add JSDoc comments to all public methods in this file.
Explain what each method does based on the implementation.
```

### Step 3: Add Tests

```
Generate characterization tests for this module.
Tests should capture current behavior, not ideal behavior.
```

### Step 4: Refactor Safely

Small, incremental changes:
```
Refactor this function to use async/await.
Keep the same behavior. Tests must pass.
```

## Real Example: Modernizing a Controller

1. Document current behavior
2. Add integration tests
3. Extract business logic to service
4. Add proper error handling
5. Verify tests still pass

## Tips

- One change at a time
- Run tests after each change
- Keep commits atomic
- Document decisions

## Common Refactors

- Callback → Promise → async/await
- Class → functional
- Monolith → modules
- Any → proper types

title: AI for Database Operations and Queries
description: Leveraging AI and MCP servers for smarter database interactions
body:
# AI for Database Operations

With MongoDB MCP, Claude can understand and query your data directly.

## Setting Up MongoDB MCP

```json
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "mongo-local": {
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["@anthropic-ai/mcp-mongo", "mongodb://localhost:27017/mydb"]
    }
  }
}
```

## What Claude Can Do

### 1. Explore Schema
```
Show me the structure of the users collection.
What indexes exist?
```

### 2. Query Data
```
Find all articles by user alex_admin.
Show me the most commented articles.
```

### 3. Debug Data Issues
```
Find users with invalid email formats.
Show articles with missing authors.
```

### 4. Generate Queries
```
Write a Mongoose query to find articles
created in the last week with more than 5 comments.
```

## Safety First

- Use **read-only** connections in production
- Limit to specific databases
- Don't expose sensitive data

## Real-World Scenario

Bug report: "Some users can't see their articles"

```
Using the MongoDB MCP, find:
1. How many articles exist
2. How many have valid authorIds
3. Any orphaned articles
```

Claude finds 5 articles with authorIds pointing to deleted users.

## Tips

- Name your MCPs clearly (mongo-prod vs mongo-local)
- Document available MCPs in CLAUDE.md
- Use for debugging, not production operations

title: Effective Documentation with AI Assistance
description: How to use AI to create and maintain useful documentation
body:
# Documentation with AI

Documentation often gets neglected. AI can help keep it current.

## Types of Documentation

### 1. Code Comments
```
Add JSDoc comments to all exported functions in @src/auth/
```

### 2. README Files
```
Generate a README for this project including:
- Setup instructions
- Available scripts
- Architecture overview
```

### 3. API Documentation
```
Document all endpoints in the articles controller.
Include request/response examples.
```

## The /doc Command

```yaml
---
name: doc
description: Generate documentation
---

Document $ARGUMENTS.

Follow these standards:
1. Clear, concise language
2. Include examples
3. Document edge cases
4. Keep it up to date
```

## Documentation Workflow

1. Generate initial docs with AI
2. Review and refine
3. Keep in version control
4. Update when code changes

## Auto-Generated Changelogs

```
Generate a changelog entry for the changes in this PR.
Follow Keep a Changelog format.
```

## Tips

- Generate docs after features are complete
- Update docs when fixing bugs
- Use AI to explain complex code
- Keep docs close to code

## What Not to Document

- Obvious things
- Implementation details that change
- Things the code already says

title: Skills and SubAgents: Claude's Extended Capabilities
description: Understanding how Skills and SubAgents make Claude Code more powerful
body:
# Skills and SubAgents

Beyond commands, Claude Code has Skills and SubAgents that extend its capabilities.

## The Spectrum

| Type | Invocation | Purpose |
|------|------------|----------|
| Commands | You (`/commit`) | Explicit workflows |
| Skills | Claude (auto) | Context-triggered |
| SubAgents | Claude (delegates) | Specialized tasks |

## Skills

Skills are discovered automatically based on context.

Example: When Claude detects lint errors, it might automatically use the `quality-check` skill.

Defining Skills:
```yaml
---
name: quality-check
trigger: auto  # Claude decides when to use
---
```

## SubAgents

SubAgents are specialized workers for complex tasks.

### The Plan Agent
```
/plan Add user authentication
```

The Plan SubAgent:
1. Explores the codebase
2. Identifies relevant patterns
3. Creates a detailed plan
4. Returns control to main agent

### The Explore Agent
For codebase exploration:
```
Use Explore agent to understand how errors are handled
```

## Creating Custom Skills

```yaml
---
name: security-check
trigger: auto
description: Check for security issues
---

Scan for common security vulnerabilities:
- SQL injection
- XSS
- Sensitive data exposure
```

## When Skills Trigger

- After code changes
- When errors are detected
- Based on file types
- Pattern matching

## Tips

- Watch the log to see skills in action
- Create skills for repetitive patterns
- Let Claude decide when to use them

title: Setting Up Claude Code for Team Success
description: Best practices for rolling out Claude Code across development teams
body:
# Team Setup for Claude Code

Rolling out AI tools to a team requires planning. Here's how to do it right.

## Prerequisites

1. **Licenses**: Ensure everyone has access
2. **Installation**: Standard installation process
3. **Configuration**: Shared settings

## Shared Configuration

### Project-Level
- CLAUDE.md in repository
- Commands in .claude/commands/
- MCP configs in .claude/settings.json

### Team-Level
- Shared MCP servers
- Common commands library
- Coding standards documentation

## Training Plan

### Week 1: Basics
- Installation verification
- First interactions
- CLAUDE.md exploration

### Week 2: Workflows
- /commit and /pr
- Plan Mode
- File references

### Week 3: Advanced
- Custom commands
- MCP usage
- Skills and SubAgents

## Addressing Concerns

| Concern | Response |
|---------|----------|
| "AI will replace me" | AI augments, not replaces |
| "I don't trust AI code" | Review and test everything |
| "It's too slow" | Show productivity gains |
| "Learning curve" | Gradual adoption |

## Success Metrics

- Time to resolution
- Code review speed
- Developer satisfaction
- Bug rates

## Tips

1. Start with enthusiasts
2. Share wins in team chat
3. Create team commands together
4. Iterate on workflows

title: CI/CD Integration with Claude Code
description: Integrating AI assistance into your continuous integration workflows
body:
# CI/CD Integration

Claude Code can enhance your CI/CD pipeline in several ways.

## Pre-Commit Hooks

Run quality checks before commits:

```yaml
# .husky/pre-commit
claude --command quality-check --auto
```

## PR Reviews

Automate first-pass reviews:

```yaml
# .github/workflows/review.yml
- name: AI Review
  run: |
    claude --command review --context ${{ github.event.pull_request.diff_url }}
```

## Commit Message Validation

Ensure conventional commits:

```bash
# Validate commit message
claude "Is this commit message following conventional commits? '$MSG'"
```

## Test Generation

Generate tests for new code:

```yaml
- name: Check Test Coverage
  run: |
    claude --command generate-tests --files changed
```

## Documentation Updates

Keep docs in sync:

```yaml
- name: Update Docs
  run: |
    claude --command doc-check
```

## Practical Limits

- **Rate limits**: Be mindful of API usage
- **Speed**: AI calls add latency
- **Reliability**: Have fallbacks

## Best Practices

1. Use for non-blocking checks
2. Cache responses where possible
3. Run AI checks in parallel
4. Human review for critical changes

## Sample Workflow

1. Developer pushes
2. CI runs tests
3. AI reviews changes (non-blocking)
4. Human reviewer sees AI summary
5. Faster, more informed reviews

title: Handling Errors and Edge Cases with AI
description: Using AI to identify and handle error scenarios in your code
body:
# Error Handling with AI

AI is excellent at identifying edge cases you might miss.

## Finding Edge Cases

```
Analyze the createArticle function.
What edge cases might cause issues?
```

Claude identifies:
- Empty title
- Very long title (slug issues)
- Missing required fields
- Invalid authorId
- Duplicate slugs

## Generating Error Handling

```
Add comprehensive error handling to this function.
Follow the project's error patterns in @src/common/errors.ts
```

## Error Messages

```
Improve the error messages in this controller.
Make them helpful for API consumers.
```

### Before
```typescript
throw new BadRequestException('Invalid');
```

### After
```typescript
throw new BadRequestException(
  'Article title must be between 1 and 100 characters'
);
```

## Defensive Programming

```
Review this function for potential null/undefined issues.
Add defensive checks where needed.
```

## Input Validation

```
Generate comprehensive validation for this DTO.
Consider all edge cases.
```

## Testing Error Cases

```
Generate tests for error scenarios in the auth service.
Cover: invalid credentials, locked accounts, expired tokens.
```

## Tips

1. Ask "what could go wrong?"
2. Review AI suggestions critically
3. Test all error paths
4. Log errors appropriately

title: My First Week with Claude Code: A Developer's Journey
description: Personal experience learning and adopting Claude Code as a new developer
body:
# My First Week with Claude Code

I was skeptical about AI coding tools. Here's how Claude Code changed my mind.

## Day 1: Installation and Confusion

Got it installed. Typed random commands. Felt lost.

What helped: The `/init` command. Claude analyzed our codebase and suddenly understood our project.

## Day 2: First Real Task

Bug report: "Users can't update their profile"

Old approach: Grep through code, add console.logs, spend 2 hours.

With Claude:
```
Users report they can't update profiles.
Find and fix the issue.
```

20 minutes. Bug found. Fixed. Tested.

## Day 3: The Wow Moment

Asked Claude to add a new endpoint. Watched it:
1. Read existing patterns
2. Create controller method
3. Update service
4. Add DTO validation
5. Generate tests

All consistent with our codebase. Mind blown.

## Day 4: Learning Prompting

Realized my prompts were too vague. Started being specific:
- Reference files
- State constraints
- Define success

Results improved dramatically.

## Day 5: Team Adoption

Shared my experience. Skeptics became curious.

## Lessons Learned

1. The learning curve is real but short
2. Be specific in prompts
3. Trust but verify
4. It's an augmentation, not replacement
5. The time savings are real

## What's Next

Exploring MCPs and custom commands. The possibilities feel endless.

title: TypeScript and Claude Code: A Perfect Match
description: How Claude Code leverages TypeScript types for better code understanding
body:
# TypeScript and Claude Code

TypeScript makes Claude Code even more powerful. Here's why.

## Type-Aware Suggestions

Claude reads your types and generates type-safe code:

```
Create a function to merge two User objects
```

Claude knows:
- User interface definition
- Which fields are required
- Field types

## Better Refactoring

```
Change userId from string to number across the codebase
```

Claude:
1. Finds all usages
2. Updates types
3. Fixes type errors
4. Updates tests

## Interface Generation

```
Generate TypeScript interfaces for the API responses in @src/articles/
```

## Type Error Fixes

```
Fix all TypeScript errors in @src/auth/
```

Claude understands the type system and makes valid fixes.

## Advanced Types

Claude handles:
- Generics
- Conditional types
- Mapped types
- Utility types

```
Create a DeepReadonly type utility
```

## Tips for TypeScript Projects

1. Keep types up to date
2. Use strict mode
3. Let Claude generate types from runtime data
4. Ask Claude to explain complex types

## Common Tasks

- Generate DTOs from schemas
- Create type guards
- Add generics to functions
- Convert JavaScript to TypeScript

title: Security Considerations When Using AI Coding Tools
description: How to use AI coding assistants safely without exposing sensitive data
body:
# Security with AI Coding Tools

AI tools are powerful, but security matters. Here's how to stay safe.

## What Gets Sent to AI

- Code you share
- Files you reference
- Error messages
- Context from your project

## What NOT to Share

### Environment Variables
```
# .gitignore
.env
.env.local
*.pem
```

Never reference .env files directly:
```
# Bad
Look at @.env

# Good
I have a DATABASE_URL environment variable
```

### API Keys and Secrets

Don't paste:
- API keys
- Tokens
- Passwords
- Private keys

### Sensitive Data

- Customer data
- PII
- Financial information

## MCP Security

### Use Read-Only Connections
```json
{
  "mongo-prod": {
    "readOnly": true
  }
}
```

### Limit Scope
Connect to development databases, not production.

## Code Review for AI-Generated Code

Always review for:
- Hardcoded credentials
- Insecure patterns
- Exposed endpoints
- Missing validation

## Best Practices

1. Use .gitignore properly
2. Never share production credentials
3. Review all AI-generated code
4. Use development/sandbox environments
5. Train team on security awareness

## Emergency Response

If you accidentally shared secrets:
1. Rotate immediately
2. Check access logs
3. Document the incident

title: Exploring Codebases with the Explore Agent
description: Using the Explore agent to quickly understand unfamiliar code
body:
# The Explore Agent

Joining a new project? The Explore agent is your guide.

## What is the Explore Agent?

A specialized SubAgent designed for codebase exploration. It reads, searches, and synthesizes information about your project.

## When to Use It

- New project onboarding
- Understanding unfamiliar modules
- Finding specific implementations
- Architecture discovery

## How to Use

### Implicit
Claude automatically uses Explore for questions like:
```
How does authentication work in this project?
```

### Explicit
```
Use the Explore agent to find all error handling patterns
```

## Example Explorations

### Architecture Overview
```
Explain the architecture of this project.
Show me the main modules and their responsibilities.
```

### Finding Patterns
```
How do we handle database transactions?
Show me examples from the codebase.
```

### Tracing Flows
```
Trace the request flow from /api/articles to the database.
```

### Finding Similar Code
```
Find all places where we validate email addresses.
```

## Tips

1. Be specific about what you're looking for
2. Ask for examples
3. Request file paths for reference
4. Follow up for deeper understanding

## Limitations

- Large codebases need focused queries
- Some context might be missed
- Always verify important findings

title: From Cursor to Claude Code: A Migration Guide
description: How to transition from Cursor IDE to Claude Code while keeping your favorite workflows
body:
# From Cursor to Claude Code

Using Cursor and curious about Claude Code? Here's how they work together.

## Key Differences

| Feature | Cursor | Claude Code |
|---------|--------|-------------|
| Interface | IDE | CLI |
| Autocomplete | Yes | No |
| Multi-file edits | Limited | Excellent |
| Extensibility | Limited | MCP, Commands |
| Agentic execution | Limited | Full |

## What Changes

### From: Cursor Chat
```
In the sidebar: "Add a new endpoint"
```

### To: Claude Code
```bash
claude "Add a new endpoint for user favorites"
```

## What Stays the Same

Your IDE! Claude Code works alongside any editor:
- VS Code
- Cursor
- Vim
- Whatever you prefer

## Recommended Setup

1. **Keep Cursor** for autocomplete
2. **Add Claude Code** for complex tasks
3. **Use both** based on task type

## Workflow Examples

### Simple Edit (Cursor)
- Tab completion
- Quick fixes
- Small refactors

### Complex Task (Claude Code)
```bash
claude /plan Add authentication to the API
claude /develop
claude /quality-check
claude /commit
```

## Migration Tips

1. Start with familiar tasks
2. Learn CLI shortcuts
3. Set up aliases
4. Explore MCP servers
5. Build custom commands

## The Best of Both Worlds

Cursor's autocomplete + Claude Code's power = Maximum productivity

title: Real-World Bug Fixes with Claude Code
description: Case studies of actual bugs fixed with AI assistance
body:
# Real Bug Fixes with Claude Code

Let's look at actual bugs I fixed with AI help.

## Case 1: The Silent Failure

**Symptom**: Articles sometimes don't save

**Investigation**:
```
Users report articles occasionally don't save.
No errors in logs.
Investigate the article creation flow.
```

**Finding**: Race condition in slug generation

**Fix**: Added proper async handling

**Time**: 15 minutes (vs estimated 2 hours)

## Case 2: The Memory Leak

**Symptom**: Server memory grows over time

**Investigation**:
```
Using MongoDB MCP, analyze connection patterns.
Check for connection leaks.
```

**Finding**: Connections not being closed in error paths

**Fix**: Added proper finally blocks

## Case 3: The Pagination Bug

**Symptom**: Page 2 shows same results as page 1

**Investigation**:
```
Analyze the pagination in articles.service.ts.
Find why offset isn't working.
```

**Finding**: Offset calculated incorrectly

**Fix**: `offset = (page - 1) * limit`

## Case 4: The Auth Edge Case

**Symptom**: Some users can't log in

**Investigation**:
```
Find users who have login issues.
Check their account data for patterns.
```

**Finding**: Users with special characters in password

**Fix**: Proper encoding in auth flow

## Patterns

1. Describe symptoms clearly
2. Ask Claude to investigate
3. Verify the finding
4. Let Claude suggest fix
5. Test thoroughly

title: The Quick Memory Feature: # Syntax
description: Using the # syntax to quickly add notes to CLAUDE.md during your session
body:
# Quick Memory with # Syntax

Need to remember something? Use the # syntax.

## How It Works

Type `#` followed by your note:

```
# Always use camelCase for variable names
```

This gets added to your CLAUDE.md automatically.

## Use Cases

### Coding Standards
```
# Use async/await, not callbacks
# All errors should be HttpException
```

### Project-Specific Info
```
# Main database is PostgreSQL, cache is Redis
# API prefix is /api/v2
```

### Temporary Notes
```
# Working on feature-xyz branch
# PR #123 needs review
```

### Lessons Learned
```
# Don't modify legacy auth module
# UserService is deprecated, use AuthService
```

## Where Notes Go

Notes are appended to your project's CLAUDE.md under a "Quick Notes" section.

## Best Practices

1. Keep notes concise
2. Remove outdated notes
3. Promote important notes to proper sections
4. Review notes periodically

## Session vs Permanent

Quick notes persist across sessions. To remove:
1. Edit CLAUDE.md directly
2. Or ask Claude to clean up notes

## Examples

```
# API rate limit is 100 req/min
# Tests need MongoDB running
# Deploy on Fridays requires approval
```

Simple, but incredibly useful for maintaining context.

title: Python Development with Claude Code
description: Tips for using Claude Code effectively in Python projects
body:
# Python with Claude Code

Claude Code works great with Python. Here are tips for Python developers.

## Project Setup

### CLAUDE.md for Python
```markdown
## Commands

python -m pytest          # Run tests
python -m black .         # Format code
python -m mypy .          # Type checking
pip install -r requirements.txt

## Virtual Environment
Using Poetry: poetry install
```

## Common Workflows

### Add Type Hints
```
Add type hints to all functions in @app/services/
Follow PEP 484 and use modern syntax.
```

### Generate Tests
```
Generate pytest tests for @app/services/user_service.py
Use pytest fixtures for setup.
```

### FastAPI Endpoints
```
Add a new endpoint following the pattern in @app/api/articles.py
```

## Framework-Specific Tips

### FastAPI
- Reference existing routes as examples
- Claude handles Pydantic models well
- Ask for OpenAPI doc updates

### Django
- Reference models for context
- Generate migrations with Claude
- Admin configurations

### Flask
- Blueprint patterns
- Extension setup

## Python Best Practices with AI

1. Use type hints (helps Claude understand)
2. Follow PEP 8
3. Document with docstrings
4. Use virtual environments

## MCP for Python

Same MCPs work:
- MongoDB MCP for database
- Context7 for Flask/FastAPI/Django docs

title: NestJS Patterns Claude Code Understands
description: How Claude Code interprets and applies NestJS conventions
body:
# NestJS Patterns with Claude

Claude Code understands NestJS conventions. Here's how to leverage that.

## Module Pattern

Claude recognizes:
- `@Module()` decorators
- Imports/exports
- Providers
- Controllers

```
Create a new module for notifications
following the pattern in @src/articles/articles.module.ts
```

## Dependency Injection

Claude understands:
- Constructor injection
- @Injectable()
- @Inject() for tokens

```
Create a service that uses ConfigService and JwtService
```

## Guards and Decorators

```
Add a RolesGuard following the pattern of @src/common/guard/jwt.guard.ts
```

Claude creates:
- Guard class
- @Roles() decorator
- Module registration

## DTOs and Validation

```
Create DTOs for article filtering with:
- Optional tag filter
- Author filter  
- Pagination
Use class-validator decorators.
```

## Pipes and Interceptors

Claude knows NestJS patterns:
```
Create a logging interceptor that:
- Logs request method and URL
- Logs response time
- Follows project patterns
```

## Testing

```
Generate unit tests for ArticlesService
Use @nestjs/testing, mock dependencies
```

## Tips

1. Reference existing patterns
2. Ask for complete module structure
3. Include test generation
4. Use Context7 for NestJS docs

title: Context7: Your AI's Documentation Library
description: Using Context7 MCP to give Claude access to up-to-date framework documentation
body:
# Context7: Documentation at Claude's Fingertips

Context7 MCP gives Claude access to framework documentation in real-time.

## What is Context7?

A documentation MCP that provides:
- Framework docs (React, Vue, NestJS, etc.)
- Library docs
- API references
- Best practices

## Setup

```json
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "context7": {
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["@anthropic-ai/mcp-context7"]
    }
  }
}
```

## Usage

### Look Up Specific Topics
```
Using Context7, look up NestJS Guards documentation.
Show me how to create a custom guard.
```

### Get Best Practices
```
Using Context7, what's the recommended way to handle 
errors in FastAPI?
```

### Compare Approaches
```
Using Context7, compare NestJS pipes vs interceptors.
When should I use each?
```

## When to Use Context7

- Learning new frameworks
- Checking best practices
- Finding correct syntax
- Understanding new features

## Context7 vs Web Search

| Context7 | Web Search |
|----------|------------|
| Curated docs | All results |
| Structured | Varied quality |
| Fast | Slower |
| Offline capable | Needs internet |

## Available Documentation

- React, Vue, Angular
- Node.js, NestJS, Express
- Python, FastAPI, Django
- MongoDB, PostgreSQL
- And many more

## Tips

1. Be specific about what you need
2. Ask for examples
3. Request version-specific info
4. Follow up for clarity

title: Modes of Operation: Normal, Auto-Edit, and Plan
description: Understanding Claude Code's different operational modes and when to use each
body:
# Claude Code Modes

Claude Code has three main modes. Understanding them is key to productivity.

## Normal Mode (Default)

**How it works**: Claude asks permission before each change.

**Use when**:
- Learning Claude Code
- Reviewing each change
- Sensitive code areas
- You want control

**Example**:
```
"I'll edit src/auth/auth.service.ts to add validation.
Proceed? [y/n]"
```

## Auto-Edit Mode

**How it works**: Claude makes changes without asking.

**Activate**: Press `Ctrl+E` or select in settings

**Use when**:
- You trust the changes
- Making many edits
- Time is critical
- Working on non-critical code

**Safety**: Changes are tracked in git, easy to undo.

## Plan Mode

**How it works**: Claude can only read, not write.

**Activate**: Press `Ctrl+P` or `/plan`

**Use when**:
- Exploring unfamiliar code
- Planning large changes
- Investigating bugs
- Learning the codebase

## Mode Comparison

| Aspect | Normal | Auto-Edit | Plan |
|--------|--------|-----------|------|
| Read | Yes | Yes | Yes |
| Write | With approval | Automatic | No |
| Speed | Slower | Faster | N/A |
| Control | High | Low | N/A |
| Risk | Low | Medium | None |

## Switching Modes

- `Ctrl+P`: Toggle Plan Mode
- `Ctrl+E`: Toggle Auto-Edit
- `/plan`: Enter Plan Mode
- `/edit`: Enter Normal Mode

## Best Practice

Start in Plan Mode → understand → switch to appropriate edit mode.

title: Working with Angular and Claude Code
description: Tips and patterns for Angular developers using AI assistance
body:
# Angular Development with Claude Code

Angular's structure makes it a great match for AI assistance.

## Project Setup

### CLAUDE.md for Angular
```markdown
## Commands

ng serve               # Dev server
ng test                # Unit tests
ng e2e                 # E2E tests
ng build --prod        # Production build

## Structure
- src/app/features/    # Feature modules
- src/app/shared/      # Shared components
- src/app/core/        # Core services
```

## Common Tasks

### Generate Components
```
Create a new component ArticleCard in shared/
following the pattern of @src/app/shared/user-card/
```

### Add Services
```
Create an ArticleService in @src/app/core/services/
with CRUD operations for articles.
```

### State Management (NgRx)
```
Add NgRx state management for articles:
- Actions
- Reducer
- Effects
- Selectors
```

## Reactive Forms

```
Create a reactive form for article creation.
Include validation for:
- Required title
- Max length description
- At least one tag
```

## Testing

```
Generate unit tests for ArticleListComponent.
Use TestBed, mock the ArticleService.
```

## RxJS Patterns

Claude understands:
- Observables
- Operators
- Subscriptions
- async pipe

```
Refactor this component to use async pipe
instead of manual subscriptions.
```

## Tips

1. Reference existing components
2. Ask for standalone components (Angular 15+)
3. Include OnPush change detection
4. Request proper cleanup

title: AI Ethics in Development: A Practical Guide
description: Responsible use of AI coding tools in professional development
body:
# AI Ethics for Developers

AI tools are powerful. With power comes responsibility.

## Code Ownership

**Question**: Who owns AI-generated code?

**Answer**: You do. But you're responsible for:
- Reviewing it
- Testing it
- Maintaining it
- Any issues it causes

## Attribution

AI doesn't need credit in your commits. But:
- Be honest with your team
- Don't claim expertise you don't have
- Share AI techniques with others

## Quality Responsibility

AI-generated code must meet the same standards:
- Code review applies
- Tests required
- Documentation expected
- Performance matters

## Bias Awareness

AI can perpetuate biases:
- Review generated validation logic
- Check assumptions in generated code
- Test with diverse inputs

## Job Security Concerns

**Reality check**:
- AI augments, doesn't replace
- Understanding > generating
- Judgment is irreplaceable
- New skills needed

## Team Dynamics

- Share AI workflows
- Help skeptics learn
- Don't create AI dependency
- Maintain manual skills

## Best Practices

1. Review all generated code
2. Understand what you commit
3. Keep learning fundamentals
4. Be transparent with team
5. Use AI responsibly

## The Future

AI will improve. Developers who:
- Embrace AI tools
- Maintain core skills
- Use AI ethically

...will thrive.

title: Optimizing AI Tool Usage for Speed
description: Tips to make your AI coding sessions faster and more efficient
body:
# Speed Optimization for AI Coding

Make your AI interactions faster with these techniques.

## Prompt Optimization

### Be Specific First
```
# Slow: Multiple back-and-forth
Fix the bug
-> What bug?
The one in auth
-> Which file?

# Fast: One prompt
Fix the null pointer in @src/auth/auth.service.ts line 45
```

### Batch Related Tasks
```
# Slow: One at a time
Add validation to field A
Add validation to field B
Add validation to field C

# Fast: All at once
Add validation to fields A, B, C in @src/dto/user.dto.ts
```

## Keyboard Shortcuts

| Action | Shortcut |
|--------|----------|
| New chat | `Ctrl+N` |
| Plan mode | `Ctrl+P` |
| Auto-edit | `Ctrl+E` |
| Cancel | `Ctrl+C` |

## Pre-built Commands

Use commands instead of typing prompts:
```bash
claude /commit    # Instead of explaining commit
claude /test      # Instead of describing test needs
claude /review    # Instead of review instructions
```

## Context Management

- Start fresh for new tasks
- Reference specific files
- Use CLAUDE.md for context
- Don't repeat yourself

## Auto-Edit Mode

For trusted operations, enable auto-edit:
```
[Ctrl+E] Make these refactoring changes
```

No approval prompts = faster execution.

## Parallel Workflows

1. Start long task in one terminal
2. Continue other work
3. Review when done

## Common Time Wasters

- Vague prompts
- Reading entire files
- Too much context
- Not using commands

title: Common Mistakes When Starting with AI Coding Tools
description: Pitfalls to avoid when adopting AI-assisted development
body:
# Common AI Coding Mistakes

Learn from others' mistakes. Here's what to avoid.

## Mistake 1: Blind Trust

**The mistake**: Accepting all AI suggestions without review.

**The fix**: 
- Review every change
- Run tests
- Understand the code

## Mistake 2: Vague Prompts

**The mistake**: 
```
Make it better
```

**The fix**:
```
Refactor the authentication flow to use async/await
and add error handling for invalid tokens.
```

## Mistake 3: Ignoring Context

**The mistake**: Not using @file references.

**The fix**: Always reference relevant files.

## Mistake 4: One Giant Prompt

**The mistake**: Asking for entire features at once.

**The fix**: Break into smaller, reviewable chunks.

## Mistake 5: Never Reading CLAUDE.md

**The mistake**: Not updating or using project context.

**The fix**: Run `/init`, review CLAUDE.md, keep it current.

## Mistake 6: Skipping Plan Mode

**The mistake**: Jumping straight to changes.

**The fix**: Use Plan Mode to understand first.

## Mistake 7: Not Learning Patterns

**The mistake**: Using AI as a black box.

**The fix**: Study what Claude generates, learn patterns.

## Mistake 8: Fear of Experimentation

**The mistake**: Playing it too safe.

**The fix**: Experiment in branches, push limits.

## Mistake 9: Ignoring Git

**The mistake**: Not committing before AI changes.

**The fix**: Commit first, easy to revert.

## Mistake 10: Solo Adoption

**The mistake**: Not sharing with team.

**The fix**: Share techniques, build together.

title: Building a Personal AI Workflow
description: How to develop your own AI-assisted development style
body:
# Your Personal AI Workflow

Everyone's workflow is different. Here's how to find yours.

## Step 1: Identify Repetitive Tasks

What do you do repeatedly?
- Write commit messages
- Create boilerplate
- Write tests
- Debug issues
- Documentation

## Step 2: Create Commands

Turn repetitive tasks into commands:

```yaml
# .claude/commands/my-test.md
---
name: my-test
description: Generate tests my way
---

Generate unit tests for $ARGUMENTS.
Use Jest.
Mock external dependencies.
Include edge cases.
```

## Step 3: Establish Patterns

### Morning Routine
```bash
claude /plan "Review yesterday's changes"
claude /review
```

### Feature Development
```bash
claude /plan
# Review plan
claude /develop
claude /quality-check
claude /commit
```

### Bug Fixing
```bash
claude "Debug: [paste error]"
# Understand
claude /fix-tdd
claude /commit
```

## Step 4: Customize CLAUDE.md

Add your preferences:
```markdown
## My Preferences
- Use functional components
- Prefer composition over inheritance
- Always add error handling
```

## Step 5: Iterate

- What worked today?
- What was slow?
- What can be automated?

## Sample Workflows

### The Reviewer
```bash
claude /review → manual check → /commit
```

### The Speed Runner
```bash
[Auto-edit] /develop → /quality-check → /commit
```

### The Planner
```bash
/plan extensively → /develop → /review
```

Find what fits your style.

title: QA Automation with AI Assistance
description: How QA engineers can leverage Claude Code for testing workflows
body:
# QA Automation with AI

QA engineers can supercharge their work with Claude Code.

## Test Generation

### Unit Tests
```
Generate unit tests for the article service.
Cover: creation, update, delete, edge cases.
Mock database calls.
```

### E2E Tests
```
Generate Playwright tests for the login flow.
Test: success, invalid password, locked account.
```

### API Tests
```
Create API tests for /api/articles endpoints.
Test all HTTP methods and status codes.
```

## Test Data

```
Generate test fixtures for user testing.
Include: admin, regular user, new user, banned user.
```

## Bug Analysis

```
Analyze this bug report:
[paste report]

Suggest:
1. Reproduction steps
2. Root cause possibilities
3. Test cases to add
```

## Coverage Improvement

```
Analyze test coverage for @src/auth/.
Identify untested paths.
Generate tests to improve coverage.
```

## Regression Test Planning

```
Given these changes in the PR:
[changes]

What regression tests should we run?
What new tests should we add?
```

## Puppeteer/Playwright MCP

With browser automation MCP:
```
Capture the current state of /dashboard.
Compare with baseline screenshot.
```

## Tips for QA

1. Use AI for test generation, humans for strategy
2. Review generated tests for validity
3. Focus AI on repetitive testing tasks
4. Keep test maintenance lean

title: Managing Technical Debt with AI
description: Using AI tools to identify, prioritize, and address technical debt
body:
# Technical Debt with AI

AI can help you tackle technical debt systematically.

## Identifying Debt

```
Analyze @src/legacy/ for technical debt.
Identify:
- Code smells
- Outdated patterns
- Missing tests
- Documentation gaps
```

## Categorizing Debt

### High Priority
- Security issues
- Performance problems
- Blocking new features

### Medium Priority
- Code duplication
- Missing types
- Incomplete error handling

### Low Priority
- Style inconsistencies
- Documentation
- Test coverage

## Planning Remediation

```
Create a plan to address technical debt in auth module.
Prioritize by:
1. Risk
2. Effort
3. Value
```

## Incremental Improvement

With each PR:
```
I'm working on feature X.
Are there nearby quick wins for technical debt?
(5 minutes max each)
```

## Documentation Debt

```
Document the legacy payment module.
Include:
- What it does
- Why it's built this way
- Known issues
- Future improvements
```

## Test Debt

```
Generate characterization tests for @src/legacy/payment/.
Capture current behavior, don't optimize.
```

## Tracking Progress

```
# CLAUDE.md

## Technical Debt Log
- [ ] Replace callback auth flow
- [ ] Add types to API responses
- [x] Document legacy modules
```

## Tips

1. Don't tackle all at once
2. Leave code better than you found it
3. Track and celebrate progress
4. Balance debt work with features

title: Pair Programming with AI
description: Treating Claude Code as your AI pair programming partner
body:
# Pair Programming with AI

Claude Code can be your always-available pair programming partner.

## The AI Pair Dynamic

**Traditional Pair**: Driver + Navigator

**AI Pair**: You drive, AI navigates (or vice versa)

## You Drive, AI Navigates

```
I'm about to implement user deletion.
What should I consider?
- Edge cases?
- Related data?
- Soft vs hard delete?
```

AI provides guidance while you type.

## AI Drives, You Navigate

```
Implement article favoriting.
I'll review each step.
```

Watch AI work, redirect as needed.

## Rubber Duck + Expert

```
I'm stuck on this pagination logic.
Let me explain what I'm trying to do...
[explain]
What am I missing?
```

## Code Review Partner

```
I just wrote this function.
Review it as if you were my pair.
Be critical but constructive.
```

## Learning Together

```
I haven't used Observables much.
Explain this code and help me improve it.
```

## Best Practices

### Keep Sessions Focused
- One task per session
- Clear context
- Regular breaks

### Communicate Intent
- Explain what you're trying to achieve
- Share constraints
- Ask for opinions

### Trust but Verify
- Let AI suggest
- Review suggestions
- You make final calls

## The Human Advantage

You bring:
- Business context
- User empathy
- Team knowledge
- Final judgment

AI brings:
- Pattern recognition
- Syntax knowledge
- Tireless availability
- Broad exposure

title: DevOps Integration with Claude Code
description: How DevOps engineers can use AI for infrastructure and automation
body:
# DevOps with Claude Code

DevOps workflows benefit greatly from AI assistance.

## Infrastructure as Code

Multi-stage build, minimal image size.

- Run on PR

- Deploy to prod on release
```

## Troubleshooting

### With Logs

[paste logs]
What's causing the restarts?
```

### With Datadog MCP

- Error rate last hour

## Scripting

```

## Security

Is it following least privilege?
```

## Documentation

```
Document the deployment process for new team members.
Include: prerequisites, steps, rollback.
```

## Tips

1. Use AI for template generation
2. Always review security implications
3. Test in non-prod first
4. Version control everything

title: What's Next for AI Development Tools
description: Predictions and trends for the future of AI-assisted development
body:
# The Future of AI Dev Tools

Where is this all heading? Some predictions.

## Near Future (2025)

### Better Context Understanding
- Entire monorepos in context
- Multi-project awareness
- Historical knowledge

### Deeper IDE Integration
- Claude Code + IDE = seamless
- Real-time suggestions
- Inline conversations

### Team Features
- Shared context
- Collective learning
- Team-specific models

## Medium Term (2026-2027)

### Autonomous Agents
- Background code maintenance
- Continuous refactoring
- Automated testing

### Full SDLC Integration
- Ticket → Code → Test → Deploy
- AI handles routine work
- Humans focus on decisions

### Specialized Models
- Framework-specific AI
- Company-trained models
- Domain experts

## What Won't Change

### Human Skills Still Needed
- System design
- User empathy
- Business logic
- Ethical decisions
- Team leadership

### Core Principles
- Code review matters
- Testing is essential
- Security first
- User value focus

## How to Prepare

1. **Learn AI tools now** - Get ahead
2. **Strengthen fundamentals** - AI augments, not replaces
3. **Focus on unique skills** - What AI can't do
4. **Stay curious** - Rapid change ahead

## Final Thoughts

AI tools are transforming development. The developers who embrace this change, while maintaining strong fundamentals, will thrive.

The best code will be written by humans and AI together. That's not the future — that's now.
